metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of chlorophyll content observations in the Yingke oasis and Linze grassland foci experimental areas
metadata.description:
The dataset of chlorophyll content observations was obtained in the Yingke oasis and Linze grassland foci experimental areas. Observation items included:
     (1) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with TM in Yingke oasis No. 1, 4 and 5 maize plots on May 20, 2008.
     (2) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with ASTER and MODIS in Linze grassland foci experimental areas on May 24, 2008.
     (3) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with ASTER and MODIS in Yingke oasis maize field on May 28, 2008.
     (4) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in Yingke oasis maize field on May 30, 2008.
     (5) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with OMIS-II in Yingke oasis maize field on Jun. 16, 2008.
     (6) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in Yingke oasis maize field on Jun. 29, 2008.
     (7) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) and TM in Yingke oasis maize field on Jul. 7, 2008.
     (8) Chlorophyll content synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in Yingke oasis maize field on Jul. 11, 2008.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of chlorophyll content measurement methods in agricultural and grassland environments using remote sensing technologies?
Feature Specification.Answer: SPAD chlorophyll meter, synchronized with remote sensing platforms, specific sites and times, cornfields, grassland sites, barley, alfalfa

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques using the SPAD chlorophyll meter compare between the Yingke oasis maize field sites and Linze grassland sites in terms of synchronization with remote sensing platforms?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection techniques using the SPAD chlorophyll meter involved synchronization with various remote sensing platforms at different sites. For the Yingke oasis maize field sites, measurements were synchronized with TM, ASTER, MODIS, and airborne platforms like WiDAS and OMIS-II on specific dates. In contrast, at the Linze grassland sites, the measurements were specifically synchronized with ASAR and MODIS. This indicates a variation in the choice of remote sensing platforms used for synchronization between the two types of sites.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred about remote sensing synchronization with ground-based measurements when assessing chlorophyll content in agricultural fields?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection involves synchronizing ground-based chlorophyll measurements with remote sensing techniques such as satellite and aerial imagery, using instruments like SPAD chlorophyll meters and sensors like TM, ASAR, MODIS, ASTER, and WiDAS. This approach allows for time-specific data collection that aligns with satellite overpasses and aerial flights, providing comprehensive insights into chlorophyll content across different observation areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on data accuracy and completeness when using SPAD chlorophyll meters in conjunction with aerial and satellite remote sensing for data collection in agricultural and grassland areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using SPAD chlorophyll meters in conjunction with aerial and satellite remote sensing can enhance data accuracy and completeness by providing ground-truth validation for remote sensing data. This method allows for the calibration of satellite imagery with precise, localized measurements, ensuring that the chlorophyll content data collected from remote sensing platforms corresponds accurately to actual field conditions. The integration of these methods can result in more reliable datasets for understanding vegetation health and productivity over large areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective of synchronizing chlorophyll content measurements with various remote sensing technologies like TM, ASAR, MODIS, ASTER, and WiDAS?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to obtain ground-truth data that can be used to calibrate and validate the remote sensing observations, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the satellite and airborne data in estimating chlorophyll content in agricultural and grassland areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are utilized to synchronize ground-based chlorophyll content measurements with airborne and satellite remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The synchronization involves taking chlorophyll content measurements on specific dates that coincide with the passage of satellite sensors such as TM, ASAR, MODIS, and ASTER, as well as airborne instruments like the WiDAS and OMIS-II. This ensures that ground-based data can be accurately correlated with remote sensing observations.
